results.title: La Guerre Est Finie = the War Is Over
results.creator_credit: Alain Resnais, Europa Films and Sofracima
results.brief_description:
Diego has spent his life working for a revolutionary group still fighting the battles of 1936 in a Spain that no longer exists. Living in Paris Diego makes repeated trips to Spain to work for the cause. Through his close collaboration with Jorge Semprun, the Spanish novelist then in exile, Resnais constructs the tragedy of a man who has come to question the very thing that has defined the value of his existence. He is bound to continue ‘the war’ but for him it is now more personal than political. Diego’s relationships with two women represent the myth and reality of his political life. The rhythms of the film are harnessed to Diego’s subjectivity - the memories, imaginings and connections in his mind together with moments of profound feeling. Also available on VHS (NLA #2081353).

Credits: Director, Alain Resnais ; writer, Jorge Semprun ; photography, Sacha Vierny ; music, Giovanni Fusco ; editor, Eric Pluet.
Cast: Yves Montand, Ingrid Thulin, Genevieve Bujold, Jean Bouise, Antoine Vitez, Gerard Lartigau, Bernard Fresson.

results.title: Pic et Pic et Colegram = Eeeny, Meeny, Miney Moe
results.brief_description:
Two small Jewish children in Nazi-occupied France are placed with a sombre family of Protestant farmers in the Cevennes to hide from persecutions. Further viewing: The documentary ‘Weapons of the Spirit’ (# 2048011, Vhs).

Credits: Producer, Pierre Meurisse ; director, Rachel Weinberg ; writer, Rachel Weinberg ; photography; Jean-Jacques Renon ; music, Georghe Zamfir, Janko Nilovic.
Cast: Monique Chaumette, Henri Garcin, Hans Meyer, Laurence Klejman, Ivan Erimitchoi, Francine Berge [narration].

results.title: Orphee = Orpheus
results.brief_description:
Cocteau’s updating of the Orpheus legend which haunted his own life takes the poet, from contemporary Paris to a mysterious chateau ruled by an imperious Princess, who first claims a younger poet, then Orpheus’ wife, Eurydice. With its unforgettable imagery of leather-clad motorcyclists, the eerie ruins of the Zone and messages from another world received by car radio, this has had a profound influence on both Hollywood and the avant-garde. Awards: Venice Film Festival 1950: Fipresci Prize ; British Academy Awards 1950: Best Film. See also: ‘Le Sang d’Un Poete’ (Blood of a Poet, 1930)[0107789, 16mm] and ‘Le Testament d’Orphee’ (1960) [X000058, 16mm] & ‘The Orpheus Trilogy’ (VHS) [2083267].

Credits: Producer, Andre Paulve ; director, writer, Andre Paulve ; photography, Nicolas Hayer ; music, Georges Auric.
Cast: Jean Marais, Francois Perier, Maria Casares, Marie Dea.

results.title: L'affiche Rouge = the Red Poster
results.brief_description:
In order celebrate the memory of the Manouchian group, a resistance network exterminated in 1944, actors reconstitute the climate of the Occupation in a theatre ‘La Cartoucherie de Vincennes’. During the show, survivors, friends and relatives of the victims speak up … Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1976.

Credits: Producer, Jean-Serge Breton ; director, Frank Cassenti ; writers, Rene Richon, Frank Cassenti ; photography, Philippe Rousselot ; music, Carlos Carlsen, Juan Cedron.
Cast: Roger Ibanez, Pierre Clementi, Laszlo Szabo, Maia Wodeska, Malka Ribowska, Anicee Alvina.

results.title: Le Voyage a Paimpol = the Journey to Paimpol
results.brief_description:
Maryvonne works hard in a factory and one day meets and eventually falls for an attractive Algerian co-worker. Meanwhile, the workers at the factory go on strike, and Maryvonne fantasizes that she is leading them Joan of Arc-style, or as a Russian revolutionary. When a journalist arrives to record the strike, he encourages Maryvonne to write her account of the matters at hand. The journalist is based in Paimpol, and as Maryvonne travels to meet him, her dreams and his reality are set on a collision course.

Credits: Producer, Dominique Laurent ; director, John Berry ; writers, Josiane Leveque, John Berry ; photography, Bernard Zitzerman ; music, Serge Franklin.
Cast: Myriam Boyer, Michel Boujenah, Jean-Francois Garreaud, Dora Doll, Michele Brousse.

results.title: Un Drole de Paroissien = Thank Heaven for Small Favors
results.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Mocky, Henri Diamant-Berger and Jerome Goulven
results.brief_description:
The Lachaunay family, high-born aristocrats, have fallen on hard times and must resort to stripping off the doors and panelling of their Paris appartment to use as firewood. They are also threatened with eviction, but never waver from their conviction that they were born not to work. One of them, the ultra-religious Georges resorts to stealing money from offertory boxes. This is a wonderfully provocative and anti-clerical comedy, served by a subtle and humourous performance by Bourvil.

Credits: Producers, Henri Diamant-Berger, Jerome Goulven ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writer, Alain Moury, Michel Servin ; photography, Leonce-Henri Burel ; music, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Pierre Thyberhein.
Cast: Bourvil, Jean Poiret, Francis Blanche, Jean Yonnel, Jean Tissier, Solange Certain, Denise Peronne, Veronique Nordey, Jean Galland, Bernard Lavallette.

results.title: Pierrot le Fou = Crazy Pete (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
Ferdinand (aka Pierrot), dissatisfied with his Parisian life and his wife sets off to a picaresque journey across France to the South with Marianne. Along the way, they get involved with her brother and his criminal activities. Godard’s stunning study of personal and global violence uses colour in a dramatic and symbolic manner. In many ways it is a watershed film in which Godard calls his whole work in the cinema into question. It is also a summation of his work to this time, an unclassifiable film of disorientingly abrupt changes of mood combining the diary form with pulp fiction and romantic tragedy, experimentation in narration with filmed essay all heavily laden with cultural and political references. As American director Sam Fuller reflects in the picture, ‘Film is like a battleground, love, hate, action, violence, death … in one word, Emotion.’

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Anna Karina, Jean-Pierre Leaud, Dirk Sanders, Hans Meyer, Raymond Devos, Samuel Fuller.

results.title: Les Cavaliers de L'orage = the Horsemen of the Storm
results.creator_credit: Gerard Vergez and Tarak Ben Ammar
results.brief_description:
Always accompanied by his brother Ange, Jason is a fine rider and wrestling champion. He supplies horses to the local army captain, Castaing. Castaing is married to Marie, a doctor. When WWI breaks out, the two brothers enlist and are sent off to the Balkans where they meet up with Marie again. She has just lost her husband and works in a military hospital. Jealousy rears its ugly head and the brothers start to compete for her favor. Awards: French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) 1984: Best music for Michel Portal.

Credits: Producer, Tarak ben Ammar ; director, Gerard Vergez ; writers, Gerard Vergez, Daniel Boulanger ; photography, Andre Diot ; music, Michel Portal.
Cast: Marlene Jobert, Gerard Klein, Vittorio Mezzogiorno, Wadeck Stanczak, Hanns Zischler.

results.title: Baton Rouge
results.creator_credit: Rachid Bouchareb, Humbert Balsan and Jean-Pierre Mahot
results.brief_description:
Baton Rouge’ is the story of three friends, one Frenchman, Mozart, and two Beurs (see footnote), Karim and Abdenour, who dream of travelling to Baton Rouge in pursuit of the American Dream (inspired by a Mick Jagger song). After a series of sequences set in the suburbs of Paris, introducing the characters, and showing them doing various temporary jobs, a whimsical twist of fate allows the threesome to make their dream come true. The plot follows their adventures in the United States as they journey south to Louisiana. Although they encounter obstacles aplenty, and are forced by lack of money into bumming train rides or stealing from a garage, they also bathe in the warmth of a more tolerant atmosphere than they have come to expect in France.” Reference: “Questions of identity in Beur cinema: from ‘Tea in the Harem’ to ‘Cheb’”. Screen 34:4 (Winter 1993): pp 321-342. Footnote: The word Beur is derived from Parisian backslang for ‘arabe’ (Arab), and was in circulation within the immigrant community in the late 1970s. Its hybrid form reflects the conflict of identity experienced by the newly visible ‘second generation’ (as they are still called).

Credits: Producers, Humbert Balsan, Jean-Pierre Mahot ; director, Rachid Bouchareb ; writers, Rachid Bouchareb, Jean-Pierre Ronssin ; photography, Jimmy Glasberg, Pierre Dupouey ; music, John D. Faure.
Cast: Jacques Penot, Pierre-Loup Rajot, Hammou Graia, Elaine Foster, Romain Bouteille, Katia Tchenko.

results.title: Rue Cases-Negres = Black Shack Alley = Sugar Cane Alley
results.creator_credit: Euzhan Palcy, Alex Regis and Michel Loulergue
results.brief_description:
Martinique-born Palcy, in her first feature, portrays some of the realities of colonialism. Although set in the 1930s the position of the dispossessed is little changed despite the evolution of the political situation as the economy remains in the hands of Martinique-born whites. The story, based on the novel by a black writer from the island, centers on a young boy from a cane-cutter’s village and his grandmother who works hard to provide him with an education as the means of breaking out of the cycle of poverty. The third main character is an old man who tells the boy the history of his people. Awards: Venice Film Festival (1983) Best Actress for Darling Legitmus ; French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) 1983: Best First Film for director Euzhan Palcy.

Credits: Producer, Michel Loulergue, Alex Regis ; director, writer, Euzhan Palcy ; photography, Dominique Chapuis ; music, Malavoi.
Cast: Garry Cadenat, Darling Legitmus, Douta Seck.
